column2: The facts so established should be consistent only with the hypothesis of the guilt of
the accused, that is to say, they should not be explainable on any other hypothesis
except that the accused is guilty.
The circumstances should be of a conclusive nature and tendency.
They should exclude every possible hypothesis except the one to be proved; and
there  must  be  a  chain  of  evidence  so  complete  as  not  to  leave  any  reasonable
ground for the conclusion consistent with the innocence of the accused and must
show that in all human probability the act must have been done by the accused.
